item.title: Jon Kyl, Former Arizona Senator, Says He Has Dementia
item.description: The Republican served for almost three decades in Congress. He said he was withdrawing from public life after the diagnosis.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

media:content.media:credit: Peter W. Stevenson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Jon Kyl speaking to reporters on Capitol Hill in 2012.

item.title: El ataque de la CIA en Venezuela: lo que hay que saber
item.description: La operación con drones, que se dijo ocurrió en un muelle donde se preparaban drogas para cargarlas en lanchas, representó una nueva escalada de la campaña del gobierno de Trump contra Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Un dron estadounidense MQ-9 Reaper en un aeródromo de Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, la semana pasada. La CIA utilizó un dron para atacar un presunto centro de narcotráfico en Venezuela.

item.title: Last Orders, London?
item.description: A tale of two cities, told through its pubs.
item.dc:creator: Jimmy McIntosh

media:content.media:credit: Jack Kenyon for The New York Times

item.title: Brigitte Bardot’s Legacy of Racist Rhetoric
item.description: The actress, who died this week at 91, was an icon of 1960s cinema. She was also a hero to the French far right.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

media:content.media:credit: Pascal Pavani/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Brigitte Bardot, center, appeared in court in 1997 on charges of inciting racial hatred.

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, of Kennedy Family, Dies at 35
item.description: Tatiana Schlossberg, an environmental journalist and daughter of Caroline Kennedy, passed away after suffering from leukemia.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Sonia Moskowitz/Globe Photos via ZUMA
media:content.media:description: Tatiana Schlossberg in 2019. After learning of her cancer diagnosis, she wrote, “I did not — could not — believe that they were talking about me.”

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 31, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 31, 2025.

item.title: Slow Flood Recovery Stirs Anger in Far-Flung Corner of Indonesia
item.description: Protests have erupted in Aceh Province on the northern tip of Sumatra island, where anger and frustration are mounting over what many see as inadequate relief efforts by a distracted government.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti

item.title: Inside China’s Six-Decade Campaign to Dominate Rare Earths
item.description: From Deng Xiaoping to Xi Jinping, generations of Communist Party bosses and military leaders invested in a strategic but heavily polluting industry.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.description: The Baitul Makmur mosque and the surrounding area swept away by floodwaters in Sekumur village.
Palm oil trees were flattened by flash flooding in Babo village in Aceh Tamiang regency, in Aceh Province.
A police helicopter delivering relief supplies in December in Babo village, part of the area affected by flash flooding in Aceh Province, Indonesia.
Motorcyclists carrying food and other supplies from Seni Antara back to villages that were cut off by landslides.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Mamdani Finds Inspiration at Old City Hall Subway Station
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 31, 2025.

item.title: Justice Dept. Now Said to Be Reviewing 5.2 Million Pages of Epstein Files
item.description: The number represents a more precise, and potentially much larger, figure than earlier estimates. The department is seeking to enlist about 400 lawyers to help in the review.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett

media:content.media:credit: U.S. Justice Department, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein with Ghislaine Maxwell in an image released by the Justice Department. The department is looking to review roughly 5.2 million pages of Epstein files documents.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 31, 2025
item.description: Jeffrey Martinovic gives us the last laugh of 2025.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

media:content.media:credit: Erik Jacobs for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rally your enthusiasm to smash the last crossword puzzle of the year.

item.title: Isiah Whitlock Jr., Scene-Stealing Character Actor in ‘The Wire,’ Dies at 71
item.description: In one of his most enduring roles, he played a corrupt state senator known for his ability to fashion an expletive into an outstretched catchphrase.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Katherine Marks for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Isiah Whitlock Jr. also performed in a number of Spike Lee films, including “25th Hour.”

item.title: Mamdani Nominates Top City Lawyer and Deputy Mayor of Health
item.description: The mayor-elect said the selections indicate his administration’s commitment to help New York City’s vulnerable residents.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Steven Banks, the former head of the Legal Aid Society, will serve as New York City’s top lawyer in the administration of Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani.

item.title: Ben Nighthorse Campbell, Former Colorado Senator, Dies at 92
item.description: A Democrat turned Republican, he was the only Native American during three terms in the House of Representatives and in 12 years in the Senate. He was also a judo expert and an Olympian.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.category: National Museum of the American Indian

media:content.media:credit: Carol T. Powers for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ben Nighthorse Campbell in 2004, when he announced he would retire from the Senate. His relatively modest legislative accomplishments included the establishment of the National Museum of the American Indian in Washington.

item.title: Iowa Democrat Wins State Senate Seat, Fending Off G.O.P. Supermajority
item.description: By holding a left-leaning seat in suburban Des Moines, Democrats ensured that Republicans would not have a supermajority in the State Senate.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:credit: Cody Scanlan/The Register, via USA TODAY, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: Renee Hardman, a member of the West Des Moines City Council, held a left-leaning suburban seat for the Democratic Party.

item.title: Health Dept. Pauses Child Care Funding to Minnesota, Citing State’s Fraud Scandal
item.description: The pause affects a funding stream that provides $185 million in annual aid to the state’s day care centers, as federal investigations into fraud in Minnesota’s social services programs continue.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk and Ernesto Londoño

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents executed a raid connected to a fraud investigation in Bloomington, Minn., earlier this month, amid broader scrutiny of fraud in Minnesota’s safety-net programs.

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg Was a Kennedy, and a Rookie Reporter
item.description: Tatiana Schlossberg, who died on Tuesday, was the granddaughter of John F. Kennedy. But as a journalist, her first editor remembers, she insisted on putting in the work.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Sforza

media:content.media:credit: Kevin R. Wexler/The Bergen Record
media:content.media:description: Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of John F. Kennedy and daughter of Caroline Kennedy, on her first day at The Record in 2012.

item.title: Mamdani Chooses a Veteran N.Y.C. Education Leader as Schools Chancellor
item.description: The selection of Kamar Samuels, who leads schools on the West Side of Manhattan, could help Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani craft his schools agenda.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson

media:content.media:credit: Sean Zanni/Patrick McMullan, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Kamar Samuels, a veteran of New York City’s public schools, is expected to be named schools chancellor by Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani.

item.title: Raymond’s Biggest Question About the Trip
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong sets out on his journey to Antarctica and shares his biggest question for the trip ahead.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Leila Medina and Phil Caller

item.title: Iowa State Senate District 16 Special Election Results 2025: Hardman Wins
item.description: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Iowa special election.

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Muere Tatiana Schlossberg, hija de Caroline Kennedy
item.description: La periodista e hija de Caroline Kennedy, relató su batalla contra un raro tipo de leucemia este año. “Ahora he añadido una nueva tragedia”, escribió en The New Yorker, “a la vida de nuestra familia, y no hay nada que pueda hacer para impedirlo”.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

media:content.media:credit: Sonia Moskowitz/Globe Photos vía ZUMA
media:content.media:description: Tatiana Schlossberg en 2019. Tras conocer su diagnóstico de cáncer, escribió: “No creía, no podía creer, que estuvieran hablando de mí”.

item.title: Masashi Ozaki, Japan’s Dominant Golfer Known as ‘Jumbo,’ Dies at 78
item.description: A World Golf Hall of Famer who could drive a ball more than 300 yards in his prime, he recorded 113 victories.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

media:content.media:credit: Mark Newcombe/Visions in Golf, via Alamy
media:content.media:description: Masashi Ozaki competing in 1996 at the Masters Tournament in Augusta, Ga. He played in the tournament 19 times but never won a major.

item.title: Justice Dept. Leaders Pushed to Charge Abrego Garcia, Emails Show
item.description: The release of the emails raised serious questions about whether the Justice Department had misled a judge in telling him that local prosecutors had acted alone in charging Mr. Abrego Garcia.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Excerpts from the emails appeared to suggest that Justice Department leaders had played a greater role in bringing the charges than prosecutors have acknowledged so far.

item.title: Ocasio-Cortez Will Give Opening Remarks at Mamdani’s Inauguration
item.description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, whose rise to prominence foreshadowed Zohran Mamdani’s success, will speak at his swearing-in outside City Hall on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman

media:content.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez spoke at a rally in Manhattan for Zohran Mamdani during the Democratic primary in June.

item.title: Trump Pushes Venezuela
item.description: Plus, the inside story of how the U.S. split with Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser

media:content.media:credit: Henry Chirinos/EPA, via Shutterstock
media:content.media:description: Oil platforms in Lake Maracaibo in Venezuela.

item.title: 3 Hikers Are Found Dead on Mt. Baldy in Southern California, Sheriff Says
item.description: The authorities closed access to part of Mount Baldy, the tallest peak in the San Gabriel Mountains in Southern California. They cited dangerous and unpredictable terrain and weather.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Mother Is Charged With Murder in Death of 1-Year-Old Son
item.description: The baby was found unresponsive in a Queens home, where the mother had tried to kill herself, a police report said.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius

media:content.media:credit: Kyle Mazza/NurPhoto, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The medical examiner has not yet determined the cause of death for the baby, who was found after a 911 call on Monday.

item.title: 6 Takeaways on the Unwinding U.S.-Ukraine Alliance
item.description: A Times investigation reveals the inside story of the Trump administration’s chaotic push for a peace deal and its erratic role in the war.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and President Trump at Mar-a-Lago on Sunday.

item.title: Overlooked Stories
item.description: We look at some of our best stories of 2025 that you might have missed in the year’s avalanche of news.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: Evgenia Arbugaeva for The New York Times

item.title: Gaza Aid Groups Face Suspensions Under New Israeli Rules
item.description: The organizations, including Doctors Without Borders, have resisted providing Israel with detailed information about their workers.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Palestinians climbed onto a truck carrying aid near Gaza City in August.

item.title: The Separation: Inside the Unraveling U.S.-Ukraine Partnership
item.description: As President Trump sought a peace deal and Vladimir V. Putin sought victory, factions in the White House and Pentagon bled the Ukrainian war effort.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mr. Trump and Mr. Zelensky at the White House in August.

item.title: The C.I.A. Strike on Venezuela: What to Know
item.description: The drone attack, said to be on a dock where drugs were being prepared for loading on boats, represented a further escalation of the Trump administration’s campaign against Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Reuters
media:content.media:description: An American MQ-9 Reaper drone at an airfield in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, last week. The C.I.A. used a drone to target a suspected drug-trafficking site in Venezuela.

item.title: Studying the Melting Continent, if We Can Reach It
item.description: Times journalists are accompanying a group of scientists on an arduous, weekslong trip to study a key glacier in Antarctica. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown

media:content.media:credit: Jim Yungel/NASA
media:content.media:description: A calving front of the Antarctic ice sheet observed by a NASA IceBridge mission in 2014.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Deportations of South Sudanese Migrants
item.description: The decision temporarily preserved deportation protections for more than 200 South Sudanese.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk

media:content.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A 2018 peace agreement ended a yearslong civil war in South Sudan, but the country continued to be gripped by violence, unrest and kidnappings.

item.title: Fed Minutes Detail Deep Divide on Timing of Further Rate Cuts
item.description: Officials at the central bank have splintered over whether rising unemployment or elevated inflation poses the bigger economic risk.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s December meeting underscore Jerome H. Powell’s difficult task in forging a consensus among policymakers.

item.title: How to Put a Celebrity at Ease? Make a Pizza.
item.description: Times Cooking’s Pizza Interview series introduces a note of nostalgia to encourage stars to open up.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

media:content.media:credit: Taylor Miller for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Victoria Chen, a Times Cooking producer, right, made a pizza with the writer, Sarah Bahr.

item.title: Judge Rules That Trump Administration Must Continue to Fund CFPB
item.description: The Trump administration had tried to defund the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which acts as a guardrail for the safety of the financial system.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner

media:content.media:credit: Nathan Howard/Reuters
media:content.media:description: In a November memo, the Justice Department wrote that the Federal Reserve could not transfer money to the C.F.P.B. because the Fed was operating at a loss.

item.title: Mamdani jurará su cargo en una antigua estación de metro bajo el Ayuntamiento de Nueva York
item.description: Horas antes de que el alcalde electo Zohran Mamdani celebre su toma de posesión frente al ayuntamiento, se convertirá oficialmente en alcalde en una pequeña ceremonia privada.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: La antigua estación de City Hall, fuera de servicio desde 1945, es famosa por sus arcos.

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, Kennedy Daughter Who Wrote of Her Cancer, Dies at 35
item.description: An environmental journalist and child of Caroline Kennedy, she wrote of her struggle with leukemia in The New Yorker in November, drawing worldwide sympathy.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

media:content.media:credit: Sonia Moskowitz/Globe Photos via ZUMA
media:content.media:description: Tatiana Schlossberg in 2019. After learning of her cancer diagnosis, she wrote, “I did not — could not — believe that they were talking about me.”

item.title: Finn Wolfhard and Natalia Dyer of ‘Stranger Things’ Make Pizza
item.description: Watch the on-screen siblings chat about food, cooking and the final season of their show — all while making a pie in the New York Times kitchen studio.

media:content.media:credit: Taylor Miller for The New York Times

item.title: The Musicians We Lost in 2025
item.description: Listen to songs by pop visionaries, neo-soul luminaries, country-adjacent outlaws and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz

media:content.media:credit: Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Brian Wilson

item.title: Un petrolero perseguido por la Guardia Costera de EE. UU. se pinta la bandera rusa
item.description: El ejército estadounidense intentó interceptar el Bella 1 la semana pasada en el mar Caribe cuando se dirigía a Venezuela para recoger petróleo.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Nicholas Nehamas and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Encouraging Kids to Read Whole Books
item.description: Readers find a classroom trend of assigning shorter texts “troubling.” Also: Reaction to President Trump’s naming of a special envoy to Greenland.

item.title: Cornelius Eady to Recite Poem at Mamdani’s Inauguration
item.description: Cornelius Eady, a National Book Award finalist, shared an excerpt from “Proof,” an original poem he has written for Zohran Mamdani’s inauguration as mayor of New York City.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Cornelius Eady will be the inaugural poet at Zohran Mamdani’s swearing-in ceremony as mayor of New York.

item.title: Journey to the Melting Continent
item.description: The New York Times is joining an expedition by sea to Antarctica’s fastest-thinning glaciers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
